intro: Jacobaea sicca, commonly known as the Sicilian ragwort, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of North Africa. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is often found in Mediterranean climates. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are yellow and arranged in a cluster. Jacobaea sicca is known for its toxic properties, containing pyrrolizidine alkaloids that can be harmful to livestock.
